title: 115_s1360
content: The Act is titled the "International Insurance Capital Standards Accountability Act of 2017." It defines terms like "appropriate committees of Congress," "Board of Governors," "Committee," and "Secretary." Congress emphasizes the need for increased transparency in global insurance regulatory forums and supports public observer access to meetings. It also aims to reach consensus with State insurance regulators through the National Association of Insurance Commissioners on international insurance proposals. The Secretary, the Board of Governors, and the National Association of Insurance Commissioners represent the United States in negotiations on insurance issues in international forums. SEC. 4. INSURANCE POLICY ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The Insurance Policy Advisory Committee on International Capital Standards and Other Insurance Issues is established by the Board of Governors with up to 11 members representing diverse expertise in the insurance industry of the United States. The Committee includes individuals from life insurance, property and casualty insurance, and reinsurance sectors, as well as agents, brokers, academics, consumer advocates, and experts on underserved insurance communities and consumers. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to this Committee. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Insurance Policy Advisory Committee on International Capital Standards and Other Insurance Issues. SEC. 5. REQUIREMENTS FOR CONSENT TO ADOPT INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL INSURANCE STANDARDS. The Secretary and the Board of Governors must follow specific steps before agreeing to an international capital insurance standard, including publishing the text for public comment and submitting it to Congress. The international capital insurance standard must align with state-based regulations and Board of Governors' capital requirements for supervised companies. The international capital insurance standard must align with state-based regulations and Board of Governors' capital requirements for supervised companies. Reports. The Secretary of the Treasury and Chair of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System must submit an annual report and provide testimony to Congress on global insurance regulatory issues discussed at international standard-setting bodies. The annual report and testimony to Congress by the Secretary of the Treasury and Chair of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System must cover the effects of international insurance regulatory proposals on US consumer and insurance markets, their positions in international discussions, and efforts to increase transparency in global insurance regulatory forums. The International Association of Insurance Supervisors will provide public access to working groups and committees. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners can testify to Congress on relevant issues. The Secretary of the Treasury and Chair of the Board of Governors must complete a study before supporting any international insurance capital standard. The Secretary and Chair of the Board of Governors must complete a study and submit a report to Congress on the impact of the capital standard on consumers and markets in the United States. They must also provide notice to Congress when drafting the report and allow for a 60-day comment period after the report is submitted. The Secretary and Chair of the Board of Governors must provide an opportunity for public comment on the report 60 days after submission. They must also submit a copy of the report to the Comptroller General for review. Additionally, a report on efforts to increase transparency must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Efforts to increase transparency at meetings of the International Association of Insurance Supervisors by the Chair and Secretary.
